stories.body_en: The towns around Fukushima have remained practically uninhabited since the 2011 disaster, but paradoxically, nature has thrived in a surprising manner. Without human interference, forests have regenerated vigorously and wildlife has returned massively to territories it had abandoned. Although these spaces have become de facto natural reserves, concerns are growing about what would happen if population return were permitted. Scientists raise crucial ethical dilemmas: should ecological recovery be prioritized over human repatriation? Radioactivity is still present although levels have decreased considerably. If reinstallation were eventually authorized, it would be necessary to carefully balance human needs with the preservation of these unique ecosystems that have emerged during these years.
